analysis.title: Edwin A Salt
analysis.author: Kurt Wimmer
analysis.logline: A CIA agent is framed as a Russian sleeper spy and must go on the run to protect his family while uncovering a dangerous government conspiracy

concept.justification: Brilliant deconstruction of spy genre with multiple narrative reversals, combining personal stakes with high-concept geopolitical intrigue

structure.justification: Tight, propulsive three-act structure with exceptional plot mechanics, clever misdirections, and earned twists

protagonist.justification: Salt is a multi-dimensional character with complex motivations, emotional depth, and exceptional agency driving the narrative

supporting_cast.justification: Winter, Katja, and Nadja are richly drawn characters with distinct voices and meaningful narrative contributions

dialogue.justification: Sharp, economical dialogue with excellent subtext, character-revealing exchanges, and strategic humor

genre_execution.justification: Masterful spy thriller execution that both honors and subverts genre expectations with innovative set pieces and narrative complexity

originality.justification: Unique take on spy genre, blending personal drama with geopolitical intrigue, featuring unexpected emotional depth

major_weaknesses: Potentially complex plot might challenge some viewers

target_audience.note: Broad appeal across action and thriller demographics

high_concept.note: Instantly marketable spy premise with emotional core

cast_attachability.note: Multiple star-level roles for leading actors

marketing_hook.note: Clear trailer moments, dramatic chase sequences

budget_return_ratio.note: Moderate budget required with strong international market potential

comparable_success.note: Similar to Bourne and Mission: Impossible franchises

structure_analysis.act_breaks: First act: Salt's initial framing, Second act: Escape and family protection, Third act: Confrontation and resolution

characters.protagonist: Edwin A Salt/Eugene Chenkov - Complex spy with deep emotional motivations, seeking to protect family while uncovering truth
characters.antagonist: Theodore Winter - Former mentor turned primary adversary, representing institutional betrayal
supporting: Katja - Emotionally complex wife with her own agency
Nadja - Perceptive daughter understanding her father's complexity
Alexi Fodorovich - Unexpected ally with historical connection

standout_scenes.why: Combines breathtaking action with deep emotional stakes

comparable_films.title: The Bourne Identity
comparable_films.similarity: Rogue agent narrative with complex backstory

budget_tier.justification: Extensive action sequences, international locations, complex production requirements

weaknesses: Complex narrative might challenge casual viewers
Some plot mechanics require close attention
assessment.recommendation_rationale: Exceptional screenplay demonstrating elite-tier storytelling with 8.55 weighted score, zero critical failures, and 17/18 commercial viability score

film_now_assessment.lightning_test: Salt's initial framing and explosive escape from CIA headquarters creates immediate narrative tension
goosebumps_moments: Page 54: Salt's emotional reunion with daughter
film_now_assessment.career_risk_test: Absolutely - represents a genre-elevating screenplay with remarkable emotional depth
film_now_assessment.legacy_potential: High - could launch franchise with unique emotional complexity

analysis.verdict_statement: FILM NOW: EDWIN A SALT represents exceptional material that demands immediate greenlight consideration. The Lightning: A CIA agent's desperate journey to protect his family while uncovering a dangerous conspiracy. The Craft: Weighted score of 8.55 with no dimension below 8. The Commercial Case: CVS of 17/18. Angelina Jolie or Chris Pratt as Salt presents transformative star potential. Urgency: This screenplay will not remain available.
